Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Robotic Forest Inventory and Mapping
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation (SBIR) Phase I project is modernizing monitoring systems for the forestry industry, environmental sustainability, and nature conservation purposes. The estimated commercial potential on the $325 B global forestry industry is an additional $3.4 B of unlocked value through faster, cheaper, and more accurate inventory systems. Warmer temperatures have contributed to an explosion in pest epidemics that have destroyed over 120 million acres of timberland in the US since 1998. In addition, these temperatures and dead trees have exacerbated wildland fire, with annual economic damage estimated to be $350 B. The societal impact of these problems is pervasive, as smoke plumes can drift for thousands of miles and adversely affect human health and environmental pollution. One fundamental requirement to address these problems is an automated forest monitoring system, as current systems still heavily rely on manual measurements. This project will enhance scientific and technological understanding by developing autonomous and large-scale semantic mapping robotic systems for dense, natural forests to tackle these broader high-impact problems. In addition, this project will provide high-tech career opportunities in rural communities by training skilled operators to develop, deploy, and control the robot teams in forests.


This Small Business Innovation (SBIR) Phase I project will develop the first commercially viable automated timber cruise to estimate forest volume from below the canopy level. The forestry industry still relies on manual measurements because, due to fundamental technical challenges, the technology to autonomously measure tree sizes under the canopy over long distances does not exist. This project will overcome two limiting challenges: 1) Robust Autonomy Challenge: No one has achieved robust autonomy in truly 3D, unstructured, GPS-denied environments where manual control (teleoperation) is not feasible; and 2) Large-Scale Semantic Mapping Challenge: No one has attempted semantic mapping at the scale and accuracy proposed, as most demonstrations have been for a few object instantiations and without the need for precise measurement. To tackle these challenges, the project anticipates three technical results: 1) Real-time tree detection to robustly detect trees in challenging conditions; 2) Continuous-Time Semantic Simultaneous Localization and Mapping to precisely model trees over vast distances; and 3) Fast Online Motion Planning with Deep Model Predictive Control to robustly navigate unmanned aerial vehicles in cluttered forest environments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Trefos Inc (d/b/a Treeswift) is a robotics for forestry company that provides customers with services to collect, produce, and manage complex forest data. Today, the forestry industry relies on manual measurements and until now, the technology to autonomously measure tree sizes under the canopy, covering tremendous areas of timberland, does not exist. With the support of NSF through the Phase I award, Treeswift successfully built and tested a next-generation forest monitoring system consisting of both hardware and software components. The hardware consists of uniquely customized unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), and the software is built with specialized artificial intelligence algorithms, which seamlessly combine to produce data rich analytics. These analytics provide forest stakeholders with the insights they need to make critical business decisions.

The Phase I project supported Treeswift personnel in development, prototyping, and testing of the first under-canopy intelligent, autonomous UAV equipped with multiple hi-resolution sensors. This customized UAV is forestry-specific and underwent rigorous testing and evaluation of performance in customer forests all across the United States. These flights enabled collection of data that was previously impossible to capture and enabled algorithm development including a software pipeline used to detect and extract tree analytics. In addition to tree detection, Treeswift designed and tested algorithms to translate structurally complex measurements into timber volumes and key analytics used by customers to make land management decisions.

Throughout Phase I, technical decisions and requirements were informed by over 100 customer discovery interviews. Insights from these discussions continue to position Treeswift as the go-to partner in building an automated forest inventory and mapping system which is accurate, efficient, and scalable. 

Treeswift worked with partners in industry and academia. Most notably through collaborative research performed with the University of Pennsylvania, an autonomous UAV flight stack was released open-source, multiple journal articles were published, and Treeswift personnel gave many presentations to both academic and industrial centers of excellence. Additionally, Treeswift identified critical regulatory strategies including engagement with the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA), which is crucial to scaling operations. Furthermore, this Phase I award catalyzed Treeswift?s partnerships with local landowners in rural areas and brought about robotics knowledge transfer to communities previously unfamiliar with this technology. Treeswift remains committed to training a new workforce in forestry equipped with robotics skill sets.

Recently the role of forests has grown greatly beyond the timber industry. Many organizations are interested in forests for their ability to sequester carbon, and these same organizations are equally worried about the impact that forest fires can have on their business and lives. Treeswift?s technology is critical in the fight against climate change, as it provides the tools and capabilities to enable the growth of new carbon markets, protect forests against natural disasters, and optimize their resource usage. Through the course of this Phase I project, Treeswift has formed relationships with key partners and stakeholders that tackle climate, environmental, and industrial applications and envision Treeswift?s technology as critical to their current and future business operations. Treeswift is well positioned to make this technology accessible to all forest landowners and to provide actionable data on every tree.  


Last Modified: 05/02/2021
Modified by: Steven W Chen
